description.narrative: Strengthening Targeted National Capacities for Improved Decision-Making and Mainstreaming of Global Environmental Obligations

receiver-org.narrative: Government of Sudan, Republic of the
Government of Sudan, Republic of the
Government of Sudan, Republic of the
Government of Sudan, Republic of the

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: 1.1 level of completion of the In-depth SWOT and Gap analysis of existing environmental policies and legislation, and the effectiveness of their enforcement. 1.2 level of Strengthened policy and regulatory framework through improved operational interpretation, enforcement tools, and by-laws. 1.3 level of strengthened Policy and legal instruments are strengthened to catalyze the use of natural resource considerations in decision-making. 2.1 Level of strengthening of the Consultative and decision-making processes for sector mainstreaming of Rio Convention obligations are strengthened. 2.2 level of enhancement for the Targeted updating and streamlining of institutional mandates and enhanced monitoring and compliance arrangements. 2.3 Level of Demonstration for the and early implementation of integrated environmental-development best practices that reflect global environmental priorities and the Post-2015 Sustainable Development Goals. 2.4 2.5 3.1 Institutional mapping and design of an optimal environmental data and information management system (EDIMS) for the global environment. 3.2 level of satisfaction of the Development of new and improved global environmental indicators for select high priority sectoral development plan. 3.3 level of incorporation of Early implementation of the integrated environmental data and information management system through a select sectoral plan. 3.4 Resource mobilization strategy in place. 4.1 Number of stakeholders trained and raised their awareness Collectively and over the four years of project implementation, the awareness-raising workshops engage over 700 unique stakeholders. 4.2 level of Awareness is improvement d through brochures articles, public service announcement(s), and education modules. 4.3 Number of Improved Internet visibility improvement of the value of protecting the global environment to socio-economic development priorities.

comment.narrative: 1.1 There is poor institutionalization of environmental issues into national developmental planning and policy-making. 1.2 Not Available. 1.3 2.1 There is frequent overlap of responsibilities leading to actions that are incongruous to the environmental management efforts of other actors. 2.2 Limited institutional capacity, particularly at the state level, to manage, coordinate and follow-up on the national implementation of the Rio Conventions and other donor-funded projects 2.3 Sudan’s institutional arrangements for environmental management are inadequate. 2.4 Requirements of the Rio Conventions are not adequately incorporated in sectoral development planning. 2.5 3.1 Sudan’s environmental information monitoring and management system is inadequate, with outdated technology and methods . 3.2 There are insufficient technical trainings and transfer of technology needs, barriers to access new and best practice knowledge, and inadequate awareness and understanding of the public of the importance of sound environmental management. 3.3 Requirements of the Rio Conventions are not adequately incorporated in sectoral development planning . 3.4 Local environmental management and decision-making is suffering from poor data collection, management, and analysis. 4.1 Awareness of Rio Convention mainstreaming is limited, and stakeholders do not fully appreciating the value of conserving the global environment. 4.2 The population in rural areas do not have an adequate understanding of global environmental issues. 4.3 Zero. Despite the fact that many stakeholders are aware of the global environmental issues, they do not use the available information for decision-making or the development of strategic document.

1.1 SWOT and Gap analysis of existing environmental policies and legislation, and the effectiveness of their enforcements adequately completed. 1.2 Policy and regulatory framework through improved operational interpretation, enforcement tools, and by-laws have been strengthened. 2.1 In-depth analysis of institutional arrangements for mainstreaming and monitoring of Rio Convention adequately implementation. 2.2 Consultative and decision-making processes fully strengthened. 2.3 Institutional mandates to facilitate and catalyze long-term action to meet global environmental obligations are updated and streamlined. 2.4 Enhanced monitoring and compliance arrangements, e.g., environmental impact and strategic environmental assessments. 2.5 High value sectoral development plan for pilot mainstreaming exercises selected by month 6. 3.1 Institutional analysis and mapping completed with high quality. 3.3 22 Best practice technological structures for data collection, storage, and sharing designed. 3.3 EDIMS monitoring plan is tested and finalized. 3.4 Full set of data and other relevant indicators and information to include in the EDIMS . selected and adequately integrated into the EDIMS by month 30. 4.1 Project Launch and Results Conference held by months 3 and 44, involving more than 700 unique stakeholders. 4.2 a high quality level of a One-day Kick-Off Conference is held within three (3) months of project initiation, over 100 participants attend. 4.3 Two broad-based surveys are carried out by month 7 and by month 44(N>250 for each survey), including 4.4 Baseline awareness report is prepared by month 7 and 4.5 Design of public awareness campaign is completed by month 8, including 8 national and sub-national awareness-raising workshops held.

Due to the last political situation in Sudan, the project implementation was delayed for a while. The project launched in April 2019 by the recruitment of the project management team. Project Inception workshop held involving all relevant stakeholders and government decision-makers. Project board and steering committees constituted and met in regular basis. TORs for consultants prepared and recruitment started and relevant contracts issued.

1.1 In-depth SWOT and Gap analysis of existing environmental policies and legislation, and the effectiveness of their enforcement produced. 1.2 Policy and regulatory framework through improved operational interpretation, enforcement tools, and by-laws adequately developed. 1.3 Policy and legal instruments strengthened. 2.1 In-depth analysis of institutional arrangements for mainstreaming and monitoring of Rio Convention implementation. 2.2 Consultative and decision-making processes strengthened. 2.3 Institutional mandates to facilitate and catalyze long-term action to meet global environmental obligations are updated and streamlined. 2.4 Enhanced monitoring and compliance arrangements, e.g. environmental impact and strategic environmental assessments. 3.1 Institutional analysis and mapping. 3.2 Best practice technological structures for data collection, storage, and sharing designed. 3.3 bEDIMS monitoring plan is tested and finalized. 3.4 Full set of data and other relevant indicators and information to include in the EDIMS. 4.1 Two broad-based surveys are carried out. 4.2 Baseline awareness report is prepared. 4.3 Design of public awareness campaign is completed. 4.4 National and sub-national awareness-raising workshops held. 5.1 Updated focal area assessments of capacity challenges to meet and sustain Rio Convention obligations. 5.2 Cross-cutting analysis of systemic, institutional, and individual capacity development needs and priorities. 5.3 Updated NCSA Final Report that includes a Capacity Development Strategy and Action Plan.

• An institutional analysis and mapping for management of data and information necessary for mainstreaming, monitoring, and facilitating compliance with global environmental obligations was undertaken. • A technical assessment of current environmental data and information collection and generation methods, was conducted for line ministries and 18 states of Sudan. • EDIMS monitoring plan and the data and conduction of the training workshops of targeted personnel in the states. • An introductory training course was carried out on Geographical information Systems (GIS) and Geoportal database building. The number of trainees was 15out of which 13 were female trainees (87%). The trainees are government employees from 6 stakeholder federal institutions. • • 5 awareness workshop on Rio conventions for media professionals were held and attended by 101 participants (44% women). • Two articles were published each in two newspapers on, Biodiversity and ABS law in Sudan and the other on conservation of Sudan marine environment. Brochures on biodiversity, main environmental events, desertification and climate change were widely distributed in all awareness and consultative workshops. • Awareness raising and interviews on Radio and TV were held in the National Radio and TV 7 states TV channels. Topics included on biodiversity, desertification, biosafety, environmental pollution, environmental governance and climate change, • A webpage for HCENR was designed and uploaded with the link hcenr.gov.sd . it is updated almost on daily bases. The website was officially launched on 30 March, 2021 in a celebration co-sponsored by UNEP-Sudan. The Total number of page views is 12775. The number of visitors during the last 30 days is 2221, the page views is 5929 and the first time visitors is 2190. Additionally, a facebook page on environmental information and Rio Convention mainstreaming is under construction

•Improved decentralized management of the environment by establishing Environmental Councils in 9 states of Sudan. •Drafting one regulation and one operational guidance to mainstream Rio Conventions. • Conduction of a pilot mainstreaming exercises for the cost-effective implementation of the three Rio Conventions in a selected sector. • Training for technical staff at all levels on best practices for monitoring and compliance on global environmental issues. •Designing best practice technological structures for data collection, storage, and sharing. •Developing a training programme and modules on operational skills for software and data management. • Conduction of a public awareness and communication campaign targeting media professionals, academicians, private sector, local communities and government technical staff. •Implementation of a high school competition for students to understand the relationships between local and global environmental issues. • Preparing an environmental awareness module for university students. • Improving the design and content of the web pages of HCENR and other stakeholder institutions and creating an appropriate social media equivalent for HCENR.
